title: pastclim overview
text: need install library Github. step, need use devtools (haven’t done already, install CRAN install.packages("devtools"). devtools, simply use: vignette detailed step step examples use library. can find website package. , can build installing pastclim : read directly R : vignette also provides instructions install optional companion package pastclimData, simplifies task downloading storing climate simulations. Depending operating system use, might need additional packages build vignette. — NOTE: pastclim relies terra process rasters. known bug terra leads occasional message: reported. error related garbage collection, affect script correctly executed, can ignored. discussion issue can found stackoverflow
code: devtools::install_github("EvolEcolGroup/pastclim") devtools::install_github("EvolEcolGroup/pastclim", build_vignettes = TRUE) vignette("pastclim_overview",package="pastclim") "Error in x$.self$finalize() : attempt to apply non-function"

title: pastclim overview
text: need download climatic reconstuctions able work pastclim. library focuses two datasets: “Beyer2020” covers last 120k years; , project go back time, “Krapp2021” goes back 800kya. datasets, functions help download data choose variables. familiar handling netcdf files, can also use functions pastclim custom datasets. Beyer2020 Krapp2021, can get list available variables dataset : However, able use data need download data files directory choice. Note data large (100s Mb Gb). also small “Example” dataset use vignette. included package download , stored /extdata directory, can found : Beyer2020 Krapp20221, pastclim manages files necessary variable. , can download data bio01 bio05 Beyer2020 dataset (operation might take several minutes, datasets large; R pause download complete): Note need provide pastclim local path store reconstructions (case ~/paleoclimate_reconstructions, probably want different one machine). use path every time use command manipulate data. can get summary variables already downloaded (thus can used) : Note example , used directory containing example dataset; use path stored data donwloaded. Note multiple variables packed together single file, command might list variables ones downloaded originally. set path every time can cumbersome; simpler option handle climate files install companion package pastclimData: pastclimData installed, paleoclimate reconstructions stored within package download found automatically pastclim without need set path). , download Beyer2020 dataset, simply need: setting path_to_nc command , downloaded file stored companion librarypastclimData. downside storing data pastclimData , reinstall upgrade R, need redownload climate reconstructions.
code: library(pastclim) get_vars_for_dataset(dataset="Beyer2020") #>  [1] "bio01"    "bio04"    "bio05"    "bio06"    "bio07"    "bio08"    #>  [7] "bio09"    "bio10"    "bio11"    "bio12"    "bio13"    "bio14"    #> [13] "bio15"    "bio16"    "bio17"    "bio18"    "bio19"    "npp"      #> [19] "lai"      "biome"    "altitude" "rugosity" get_vars_for_dataset(dataset="Krapp2021") #>  [1] "bio01"    "bio04"    "bio05"    "bio06"    "bio07"    "bio08"    #>  [7] "bio09"    "bio10"    "bio11"    "bio12"    "bio13"    "bio14"    #> [13] "bio15"    "bio16"    "bio17"    "bio18"    "bio19"    "npp"      #> [19] "biome"    "altitude" "rugosity" path_to_example_nc <- system.file("/extdata/", package="pastclim") download_dataset(dataset="Beyer2020", bio_variables = c("bio01","bio05"),                  path_to_nc = "~/paleoclimate_reconstructions") get_downloaded_datasets(path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) #> $Example #> [1] "bio01" "bio10" "bio12" "biome" devtools::install_github("EvolEcolGroup/pastclimData", ref="master") download_dataset(dataset="Beyer2020", bio_variables = c("bio01","bio05"))

title: pastclim overview
text: Get climate several locations different times: Note last two locations, appropriate time steps, available (either water ice), pastclim return climate reconstruction. instances, due discretisation space raster. can interpolate climate among nearest neighbours, thus using climate reconstructions neighbouring pixels location just one land pixels: case, last location indeed just coast, can reconstruct appropriate climate interpolating. Note nn_interpol = TRUE default function. commands , used local copy Example dataset. pastclimData installed, use commands without setting path_to_nc. Get time series locations: resulting dataframe can subsetted get time series location (small example dataset contains 5 time points): Note last two locations return information time steps. ’s due change sea level icesheet extent, function (opposed climate_for_locations) allow interpolation.
code: locations<-data.frame(longitude=c(0,90,-120,-7),latitude=c(20,45,60,37),                       time_bp=c(0,-10000, -20000, -10000))  climate_for_locations (x= locations[,c("longitude", "latitude")],            time_bp = locations$time_bp, bio_variables=c("bio01","bio12"),            dataset="Example", nn_interpol = FALSE, path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) #>   longitude latitude time_bp     bio01    bio12 #> 1         0       20       0 27.469721 79.85666 #> 2        90       45  -10000  5.871795 74.30677 #> 3      -120       60  -20000        NA       NA #> 4        -7       37  -10000        NA       NA climate_for_locations (x= locations[,c("longitude", "latitude")],            time_bp = locations$time_bp, bio_variables=c("bio01","bio12"),            dataset="Example", nn_interpol = TRUE, path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) #>   longitude latitude time_bp     bio01     bio12 #> 1         0       20       0 27.469721  79.85666 #> 2        90       45  -10000  5.871795  74.30677 #> 3      -120       60  -20000        NA        NA #> 4        -7       37  -10000 16.986354 634.06764 locations_ts <- time_series_for_locations(x= locations[,c("longitude", "latitude")],                                          bio_variables=c("bio01","bio12"),                                          dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) subset(locations_ts,id==1) #>     longitude latitude id   time    bio01     bio12 #> 1           0       20  1 -20000 22.29012  90.42681 #> 1.1         0       20  1 -15000 23.55733 124.59431 #> 1.2         0       20  1 -10000 25.49891 143.62798 #> 1.3         0       20  1  -5000 26.15615 123.10526 #> 1.4         0       20  1      0 27.46972  79.85666 subset(locations_ts,id==3) #>     longitude latitude id   time     bio01    bio12 #> 3        -120       60  3 -20000       NaN      NaN #> 3.1      -120       60  3 -15000       NaN      NaN #> 3.2      -120       60  3 -10000 -4.152016 304.4748 #> 3.3      -120       60  3  -5000 -3.695625 368.5451 #> 3.4      -120       60  3      0 -3.614444 328.0434 subset(locations_ts,id==4) #>     longitude latitude id   time    bio01    bio12 #> 4          -7       37  4 -20000 11.81411 1211.144 #> 4.1        -7       37  4 -15000 13.98757 1138.329 #> 4.2        -7       37  4 -10000      NaN      NaN #> 4.3        -7       37  4  -5000      NaN      NaN #> 4.4        -7       37  4      0      NaN      NaN

what: Get climate for a given time step
title: pastclim overview
text: can extract rasters given time step: can get summary object: plot two layers:  Often want focus given region. number preset extents pastclim: can crop raster Europe:  might want use complex shape (.e. polygon, terra::vect object) mask limit area covered raster. example, might want focus 3 continents Africa, Europe Asia, exclude Americas Oceania. need create polygon appropriate vertices (note need reuse first vertex last vertex, close polygon). masking operation work correctly, polygon need projection raster (dataset simple lon/lat projection, can copy crs raster polygon). also helpful crop extent raster polygon (avoid large amount blank space).  pastclim includes number pre-generated masks main continental masses, stored dataset continent_outlines sf object. Note outlines cross antimeridian split multiple polygons (can used without projecting rasters). continent_outlines_union provides outlines single polygons (case want use projection). can build outline Africa nad Eurasian unioning two individual outines: Note Eurasian outline intersected antimeridian, small amount data left hand side plot (corresponding eastern end Siberia).
code: climate_20k <- climate_for_time_slice(time_bp = -20000,                                       c("bio01","bio10","bio12"),                                       dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) library(terra) #> terra 1.5.21 climate_20k #> class       : SpatRaster  #> dimensions  : 300, 720, 3  (nrow, ncol, nlyr) #> resolution  : 0.5, 0.5  (x, y) #> extent      : -180, 180, -60, 90  (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) #> coord. ref. : lon/lat WGS 84  #> sources     : example_climate.nc:BIO1   #>               example_climate.nc:BIO10   #>               example_climate.nc:BIO12   #> varnames    : bio01 (Annual Mean Temperature)  #>               bio10 (Mean Temperature of Warmest Quarter)  #>               bio12 (Annual Precipitation)  #> names       : bio01, bio10, bio12  #> time        : -20000 terra::plot(climate_20k) region_extent #> $Africa #> [1] -19  61 -36  38 #>  #> $America #> [1] -180  -15  -70   90 #>  #> $Asia #> [1]  60 180   5  85 #>  #> $Europe #> [1] -15  70  33  75 #>  #> $Eurasia #> [1] -15 180  33  85 #>  #> $N_America #> [1] -180  -15   15   90 #>  #> $Oceania #> [1] 110 180 -50  10 #>  #> $S_America #> [1] -125  -31   58   35 europe_climate_20k <- terra::crop(climate_20k,terra::ext(region_extent$Europe)) terra::plot(europe_climate_20k) afr_eurasia_vec<- terra::vect("POLYGON ((0 70, 25 70, 50 80, 170 80, 170 10,                                119 2.4, 119 0.8, 116 -7.6, 114 -12, 100 -40,                               -25 -40, -25 64, 0 70))") terra::crs(afr_eurasia_vec)<-terra::crs(climate_20k) climate_20k_afr_eurasia <- terra::mask(climate_20k, afr_eurasia_vec) climate_20k_afr_eurasia <- terra::crop(climate_20k_afr_eurasia,afr_eurasia_vec) terra::plot(climate_20k_afr_eurasia) library(sf) #> Linking to GEOS 3.8.0, GDAL 3.0.4, PROJ 6.3.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE africa_outline<- subset(region_outline, region_outline$name=="Africa") eurasia_outline<- subset(region_outline, region_outline$name=="Eurasia") afr_eurasia_vec<-terra::vect(sf::st_union(africa_outline, eurasia_outline)) #> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all #> geometries climate_20k_afr_eurasia <- terra::mask(climate_20k, afr_eurasia_vec) terra::plot(climate_20k_afr_eurasia)

title: pastclim overview
text: climate reconstructions show areas permanent ice. Ice sheets stored class 28 “biome” variable: plot , extract biome subset just class  simply, use functions designed get ice land masks.
code: get_biome_classes("Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) #>    id                           category #> 1   0                       Water bodies #> 2   1          Tropical evergreen forest #> 3   2     Tropical semi-deciduous forest #> 4   3 Tropical deciduous forest/woodland #> 5   4         Temperate deciduous forest #> 6   5           Temperate conifer forest #> 7   6                  Warm mixed forest #> 8   7                  Cool mixed forest #> 9   8                Cool conifer forest #> 10  9                  Cold mixed forest #> 11 10      Evegreen taiga/montane forest #> 12 11     Deciduous taiga/montane forest #> 13 12                   Tropical savanna #> 14 13      Tropical xerophytic shrubland #> 15 14     Temperate xerophytic shrubland #> 16 15     Temperate sclerophyll woodland #> 17 16      Temperate broadleaved savanna #> 18 17              Open conifer woodland #> 19 18                    Boreal parkland #> 20 19                 Tropical grassland #> 21 20                Temperate grassland #> 22 21                             Desert #> 23 22                      Steppe tundra #> 24 23                       Shrub tundra #> 25 24                 Dwarf shrub tundra #> 26 25             Prostrate shrub tundra #> 27 26    Cushion forb lichen moss tundra #> 28 27                             Barren #> 29 28                           Land ice climate_20k <- climate_for_time_slice(-20000,                                       c("bio01","bio10","biome"),                                       dataset = "Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) climate_20k$ice<-climate_20k$biome climate_20k$ice[climate_20k$ice!=28]<-FALSE climate_20k$ice[climate_20k$ice==28]<-TRUE terra::plot(climate_20k) climate_20k <- climate_for_time_slice(-20000,                                       c("bio01","bio10"),                                       dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) climate_20k$ice_mask<-get_ice_mask(-20000, dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) climate_20k$land_mask <- get_land_mask(-20000, dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) terra::plot(climate_20k)

what: Set the samples within the background
title: pastclim overview
text: can visualise environment time step PCA:  can now get climate variables locations time step, compute PCA scores plots locations top background climate:
code: climate_10k <- climate_for_time_slice(-10000,                                       c("bio01","bio10","bio12"),                                       dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) climate_values_10k <- values(climate_10k) climate_values_10k <- climate_values_10k[!is.nan(climate_values_10k[,1]),] climate_10k_pca<-prcomp(climate_values_10k,scale=TRUE, center=TRUE) plot(climate_10k_pca$x[,2]~climate_10k_pca$x[,1],pch=20,col="lightgray",      xlab="PC1",ylab="PC2") locations_10k <- locations[locations$time_bp==-10000,] locations_10k_climate<- climate_for_locations (x= locations_10k[,c("longitude", "latitude")],            time_bp = locations_10k$time_bp, bio_variables=c("bio01","bio10","bio12"),            dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) locations_10k_pca_scores <- predict(climate_10k_pca,newdata= locations_10k_climate[,-c(1:2)]) plot(climate_10k_pca$x[,2]~climate_10k_pca$x[,1],pch=20,col="lightgray",      xlab="PC1",ylab="PC2") points(locations_10k_pca_scores,pch=20,col="red")

previous_headings: Set the samples within the background
title: pastclim overview
text: Sometimes want work multiple time steps represent given MIS. can get list time steps available given mis : now cycle steps. First extract climate list: combine single matrix: finally plot :
code: mis_time_steps <- get_mis_time_steps(1,"Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) mis_time_steps #> [1] -10000  -5000      0 mis_climate_list<-list() for (this_step in mis_time_steps){   this_step_climate <- climate_for_time_slice(this_step ,c("bio01","bio10","bio12"),                                       dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) this_step_climate <- values(this_step_climate) this_step_climate <- this_step_climate[!is.nan(this_step_climate[,1]),]   mis_climate_list[[as.character(this_step)]]<- this_step_climate } mis_climate <- do.call(rbind, mis_climate_list) mis_pca<-prcomp(mis_climate,scale=TRUE, center=TRUE) plot(mis_pca$x[,2]~mis_pca$x[,1],pch=20,col="lightgray",      xlab="PC1",ylab="PC2")

title: pastclim overview
text: number species distribution models, need subsample background points presences. can simply generating raster time slice interest, using appropriate function terra: needed get variables coordinates, simply: Alternatively, use cell number:
code: climate_20k <- climate_for_time_slice(-20000,c("bio01","bio10"),                                       dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) this_sample<-terra::spatSample(climate_20k, 100,na.rm=TRUE,cells=TRUE,xy=TRUE) head(this_sample) #>     cell      x      y     bio01    bio10 #> 1  98825 -87.75  21.25 21.935051 24.47902 #> 2 136504  31.75  -4.75 17.739946 18.49844 #> 3  65447 143.25  44.75 -2.336489 11.06159 #> 4 161932 145.75 -22.25 19.241463 25.13065 #> 5  85461  70.25  30.75 17.893305 28.14355 #> 6 123710 114.75   4.25 21.198843 22.27645 additional_var <- climate_for_locations (             x= data.frame(longitude = this_sample$x, latitude = this_sample$y),             time_bp = rep(-20000,nrow(this_sample)),              bio_variables=c("bio12"),             dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) head(additional_var) #>   longitude latitude time_bp     bio12 #> 1    -87.75    21.25  -20000  628.7681 #> 2     31.75    -4.75  -20000 1218.9349 #> 3    143.25    44.75  -20000  928.7036 #> 4    145.75   -22.25  -20000  291.8728 #> 5     70.25    30.75  -20000  239.6058 #> 6    114.75     4.25  -20000 3206.1243 additional_var <- climate_for_locations (x= this_sample$cell,            time_bp = rep(-20000,nrow(this_sample)),             bio_variables=c("bio12"),            dataset="Example", path_to_nc = path_to_example_nc) head(additional_var) #>   cell_number time_bp     bio12 #> 1       98825  -20000  628.7681 #> 2      136504  -20000 1218.9349 #> 3       65447  -20000  928.7036 #> 4      161932  -20000  291.8728 #> 5       85461  -20000  239.6058 #> 6      123710  -20000 3206.1243

title: Authors and Citation
text: Andrea Manica. Maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Manica (2022). pastclim: package provides helper functions interact timeseries worldwide climate reconstructions. R package version 0.9.0, https://github.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim.
code: @Manual{,   title = {pastclim: This package provides helper functions to interact with timeseries of worldwide climate reconstructions},   author = {Andrea Manica},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.9.0},   url = {https://github.com/EvolEcolGroup/pastclim}, }

what:
This package provides helper functions to interact with timeseries of worldwide climate
    reconstructions
title:
This package provides helper functions to interact with timeseries of worldwide climate
    reconstructions
text: library designed provide easy way extract manipulate paleoclimate reconstructions ecological anthropological analyses. currently focuses data Beyer et al 2020, reconstruction climate based HadCM3 model last 120k years, Krapp et al 2021, covers last 800k years. reconstructions bias-corrected downscaled 0.5 degree.

title:
This package provides helper functions to interact with timeseries of worldwide climate
    reconstructions
text: need install library Github. step, need use devtools (haven’t done already, install CRAN install.packages("devtools"). devtools, simply use: vignette detailed step step examples use library. can find website package. , can build installing pastclim : read directly R : vignette also provides instructions install optional companion package pastclimData, simplifies task downloading storing climate simulations. NOTE: pastclim relies terra process rasters. known bug terra leads occasional message: error related garbage collection, affect script correctly executed, can ignored. discussion issue can found stackoverflow
code: devtools::install_github("EvolEcolGroup/pastclim") devtools::install_github("EvolEcolGroup/pastclim", build_vignette = TRUE) vignette("pastclim_overview",package="pastclim") "Error in x$.self$finalize() : attempt to apply non-function"

what: Documentation for the Beyer2020 dataset — Beyer2020
title: Documentation for the Beyer2020 dataset — Beyer2020
text: dataset covers last 120k years, intervals 1/2 k years.

title: Documentation for the Beyer2020 dataset — Beyer2020
text: dataset can downloaded download_dataset. files can found Manica, Andrea (2022): pastclim_beyer2020_v1.0.0. figshare. Dataset. https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.19723405.v1 based Beyer, R.M.,  Krapp, M. & Manica, . High-resolution terrestrial climate, bioclimate  vegetation last 120,000 years. Sci Data 7, 236 (2020).  https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-020-0552-1 version included `pastclim` icesheets masked, well internal seas (Black Caspian Sea) removed. latter based : https://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4278 https://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4282 reconstruction depth throught time, modern outlines used time steps. Also, bio15, coefficient variation computed adding one monthly estimates, multiplied 100 following https://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/691/ds691.pdf

what: Documentation for the Krapp2021 dataset — Krapp2021
title: Documentation for the Krapp2021 dataset — Krapp2021
text: dataset covers last 800k years, intervals 1k years.

title: Documentation for the Krapp2021 dataset — Krapp2021
text: dataset can downloaded download_dataset. files can found Manica, Andrea (2022): pastclim_krapp2021_v1.0.0. figshare. Dataset.  https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.19733680.v1 based Krapp, M., Beyer, R.M., Edmundson, S.L. et al. statistics-based  reconstruction high-resolution global terrestrial climate last  800,000 years. Sci Data 8, 228 (2021).  https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-021-01009-3 version included `pastclim` icesheets masked. Note , bio15, use corrected version, follows  https://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/691/ds691.pdf

what: Extract local climate for one or more locations. — climate_for_locations
title: Extract local climate for one or more locations. — climate_for_locations
text: function extract local climate Beyer et al set locations appropriate times

title: Extract local climate for one or more locations. — climate_for_locations
code: climate_for_locations(   x,   time_bp,   bio_variables,   dataset,   path_to_nc = NULL,   nn_interpol = TRUE )

title: Extract local climate for one or more locations. — climate_for_locations
text: x 2 column matrix (columns `longitude`, ranging -180 180, `latitude`, -90 90), vector cell numbers. time_bp vector ages, years present (negative). bio_variables vector names variables extracted. dataset string defining dataset use (one Beyer2020, Krapp2021 custom). path_to_nc path directory containing downloaded resonstructions. Leave unset using companion `pastclimData` store datasets. nn_interpol boolean determining whether nearest neighbour interpolation used estimate climate cells lack information (.e. water ice). Interpolation performed first ring nearest neighbours; climate available, NA returned location. Defaults TRUE.
